page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Hosni Mubarak's rule

rev.diff:
Line 3: Line 3:
The following is a chronological summary of the major events that took place during the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]] before Mubarak's resignation as the [[List of Presidents of Egypt|fourth]] [[President of Egypt]].
The following is a chronological summary of the major events that took place during the [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011]] before Mubarak's resignation as the [[List of Presidents of Egypt|fourth]] [[President of Egypt]].
â
== Before Mubarak's resignation ==
+
==25 January â Day of Revolt==
â
===25 January â Day of Revolt===
 
[[File:Day of Anger marchers with out signs.jpg|thumb|Protesters marching to [[Midan Tahrir|Tahrir Square]], in [[Downtown Cairo]], where the main protests were being held]]
[[File:Day of Anger marchers with out signs.jpg|thumb|Protesters marching to [[Midan Tahrir|Tahrir Square]], in [[Downtown Cairo]], where the main protests were being held]]
Line 12: Line 12:
Cairo protesters had gathered in the morning in front of the High Court in the centre of Cairo. The demonstration was larger than expected and able to break the security cordon and head to [[Tahrir Square]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.addustour.com/ViewTopic.aspx?ac=\ArabicAndInter\2011\01\ArabicAndInter_issue1200_day27_id299121.htm |title=3 ÙØªÙÙ ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØ«Ø§ÙÙ ÙØªØ¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø§Øª ÙØµØ± |work=Al Dustour |language=Arabic |date= 27 January 2011 |accessdate=7 February 2011}}</ref> Police used tear gas and water cannons against the protesters, who in turn threw stones at police, eventually forcing them to retreat.<ref name="bbc25jan">{{cite web| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12272836| title=Egypt Protests: Three Killed in 'Day of Revolt'| accessdate=26 January 2011| date=25 January 2011|work=[[BBC News]]}}</ref> Deadly clashes broke out during the protests. A policeman was reported to have died in Cairo, while in Suez two protesters were killed.<ref name="bbc25jan" /> It was reported that many police had also been restrained in their use of violence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70O2GG20110125?sp=true|title=Q+A-How Will Egypt's Protests Affect Mubarak's Rule?|work=[[Reuters]]|date=9 February 2009|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref>
Cairo protesters had gathered in the morning in front of the High Court in the centre of Cairo. The demonstration was larger than expected and able to break the security cordon and head to [[Tahrir Square]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.addustour.com/ViewTopic.aspx?ac=\ArabicAndInter\2011\01\ArabicAndInter_issue1200_day27_id299121.htm |title=3 ÙØªÙÙ ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØ«Ø§ÙÙ ÙØªØ¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø§Øª ÙØµØ± |work=Al Dustour |language=Arabic |date= 27 January 2011 |accessdate=7 February 2011}}</ref> Police used tear gas and water cannons against the protesters, who in turn threw stones at police, eventually forcing them to retreat.<ref name="bbc25jan">{{cite web| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12272836| title=Egypt Protests: Three Killed in 'Day of Revolt'| accessdate=26 January 2011| date=25 January 2011|work=[[BBC News]]}}</ref> Deadly clashes broke out during the protests. A policeman was reported to have died in Cairo, while in Suez two protesters were killed.<ref name="bbc25jan" /> It was reported that many police had also been restrained in their use of violence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70O2GG20110125?sp=true|title=Q+A-How Will Egypt's Protests Affect Mubarak's Rule?|work=[[Reuters]]|date=9 February 2009|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref>
â
===26 January===
+
==26 January==
On 26 January riots continued, with protesters numbering in the thousands, although no accurate estimate has yet been made. There was increased use of violence from both protesters and the police, with one protester and one police official killed in Cairo.<ref name="np26jan" /> Suez experienced a dramatic uprising; many protesters were fired upon with live ammunition, and both protesters and police were beaten. Protesters in Suez also managed to set fire to several government buildings, including the police station.<ref name="np26jan">{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalpost.com/news/world/More+casualties+protests+escalate+Egypt/4173057/story.html|title=More Casualties as Protests Escalate in Egypt|work=[[National Post]]|date=22 December 2010|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="aljazeera-448">{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112734210243448.html|title=Protesters Torch Egypt Police post|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=27 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112617427113878.html|title=Clinton Calls for reform in Egypt|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref>
On 26 January riots continued, with protesters numbering in the thousands, although no accurate estimate has yet been made. There was increased use of violence from both protesters and the police, with one protester and one police official killed in Cairo.<ref name="np26jan" /> Suez experienced a dramatic uprising; many protesters were fired upon with live ammunition, and both protesters and police were beaten. Protesters in Suez also managed to set fire to several government buildings, including the police station.<ref name="np26jan">{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalpost.com/news/world/More+casualties+protests+escalate+Egypt/4173057/story.html|title=More Casualties as Protests Escalate in Egypt|work=[[National Post]]|date=22 December 2010|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="aljazeera-448">{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112734210243448.html|title=Protesters Torch Egypt Police post|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=27 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112617427113878.html|title=Clinton Calls for reform in Egypt|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref>
â
===27 January===
+
==27 January==
[[File:Demonstration in Imaba, Cario.jpg|thumb|left|A demonstration in Cairo. The sign has an [[open source]] [[:File:Hosni Mubarak getting the boot.png|caricature]] by [[Carlos Latuff]] which features [[shoeing]].]]
[[File:Demonstration in Imaba, Cario.jpg|thumb|left|A demonstration in Cairo. The sign has an [[open source]] [[:File:Hosni Mubarak getting the boot.png|caricature]] by [[Carlos Latuff]] which features [[shoeing]].]]
Protests were not as large on 27 January as preparations were made for planned large-scale events on the following day (Friday). The Muslim Brotherhood declared full support for the protests, and members planned to take part during Friday's demonstrations.<ref name="fox-brotherhood">{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/01/27/egypts-protests-pose-threat-regime/|title=Egypt's Ruling Party Offers No Concessions to Anti-Government Protesters|publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[Fox News]]'')|date=27 January 2011}}</ref> Reformer and leader of the [[National Association for Change]] [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] returned on that day at Cairo International Airport to join the planned protests on the next day.<ref name="BaradeiArrive">{{cite news|last=Elmeshad|first=Mohamed|title=Back in Egypt, ElBaradei vows to take part in planned Friday demonstrations|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/back-egypt-elbaradei-vows-take-part-planned-friday-demonstrations|accessdate=5 February 2011|newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm|date=27 January 2011}}</ref>
Protests were not as large on 27 January as preparations were made for planned large-scale events on the following day (Friday). The Muslim Brotherhood declared full support for the protests, and members planned to take part during Friday's demonstrations.<ref name="fox-brotherhood">{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/01/27/egypts-protests-pose-threat-regime/|title=Egypt's Ruling Party Offers No Concessions to Anti-Government Protesters|publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[Fox News]]'')|date=27 January 2011}}</ref> Reformer and leader of the [[National Association for Change]] [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] returned on that day at Cairo International Airport to join the planned protests on the next day.<ref name="BaradeiArrive">{{cite news|last=Elmeshad|first=Mohamed|title=Back in Egypt, ElBaradei vows to take part in planned Friday demonstrations|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/back-egypt-elbaradei-vows-take-part-planned-friday-demonstrations|accessdate=5 February 2011|newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm|date=27 January 2011}}</ref>
Line 25: Line 25:
{{clear}}
{{clear}}
â
===28 January â Friday of Anger===
+
==28 January â Friday of Anger==
{{External media
{{External media
| video1 = {{YouTube|CAaTt-ekDw4&sk|A large car runs over protesters in Cairo}}
| video1 = {{YouTube|CAaTt-ekDw4&sk|A large car runs over protesters in Cairo}}
Line 59: Line 59:
The arson and looting that took place throughout the day has been compared to the disorder that befell Cairo during the [[Cairo Fire|1952 fire]], also known as Black Saturday.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Muhammad |first=Mohsen |date=3 February 2011 |title=Ø®Ø³Ø§Ø±Ø© |trans_title=Khusara |journal=[[Al Gomhuria]] |language=Arabic |accessdate=2011-02-06 |url=http://www.alarabiya.net/views/2011/02/03/136071.html |format=Reprint}}</ref>
The arson and looting that took place throughout the day has been compared to the disorder that befell Cairo during the [[Cairo Fire|1952 fire]], also known as Black Saturday.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Muhammad |first=Mohsen |date=3 February 2011 |title=Ø®Ø³Ø§Ø±Ø© |trans_title=Khusara |journal=[[Al Gomhuria]] |language=Arabic |accessdate=2011-02-06 |url=http://www.alarabiya.net/views/2011/02/03/136071.html |format=Reprint}}</ref>
â
===29 January===
+
==29 January==
[[File:Demonstrators on Army Truck in Tahrir Square, Cairo.jpg|thumb|left|Demonstrators standing on an army vehicle in [[Tahrir Square]], Cairo. The sign reads: "Leave, you tyrant. Down with Mubarak."]]
[[File:Demonstrators on Army Truck in Tahrir Square, Cairo.jpg|thumb|left|Demonstrators standing on an army vehicle in [[Tahrir Square]], Cairo. The sign reads: "Leave, you tyrant. Down with Mubarak."]]
Line 76: Line 76:
Many tourists sites have been disrupted, with access to the [[Pyramids]] in [[Giza]] suspended.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Egypt Closes Off Access to Famed Pyramids, Other Sites, as Protests Enter Fifth Day|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/106554/20110129/egypt-mubarak.htm|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[International Business Times]]|date=29 January 2011<!-- 9:31 am EST-->}}</ref> The resort town of [[Sharm-el Shaikh]], however, has been calm.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Wingfield-Hayes|first=Rupert|title=No Sense of Any Crisis in Sharm El-Sheikh|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/12320129|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[BBC News]]|date=30 January 2011}}</ref> Chaos had been reported at [[Cairo International Airport]], where thousands of stranded and frightened foreigners are attempting to be evacuated back to their home countries.<ref name="english.aljazeera.net">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/20111316148317175.html|title=Egypt Protesters Increase Pressure|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=31 January 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref>
Many tourists sites have been disrupted, with access to the [[Pyramids]] in [[Giza]] suspended.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Egypt Closes Off Access to Famed Pyramids, Other Sites, as Protests Enter Fifth Day|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/106554/20110129/egypt-mubarak.htm|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[International Business Times]]|date=29 January 2011<!-- 9:31 am EST-->}}</ref> The resort town of [[Sharm-el Shaikh]], however, has been calm.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Wingfield-Hayes|first=Rupert|title=No Sense of Any Crisis in Sharm El-Sheikh|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/12320129|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[BBC News]]|date=30 January 2011}}</ref> Chaos had been reported at [[Cairo International Airport]], where thousands of stranded and frightened foreigners are attempting to be evacuated back to their home countries.<ref name="english.aljazeera.net">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/20111316148317175.html|title=Egypt Protesters Increase Pressure|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=31 January 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref>
â
===30 January===
+
==30 January==
[[File:2011 Egypt protests - graffiti on military vehicle.jpg|thumb|left|A [[Armoured personnel carrier|troop carrier]] defaced with protester graffiti, the larger of which reads "Down with Mubarak", "No to Mubarak", "Mubarak the dictator has fallen" and "Leave, you thief!"]]
[[File:2011 Egypt protests - graffiti on military vehicle.jpg|thumb|left|A [[Armoured personnel carrier|troop carrier]] defaced with protester graffiti, the larger of which reads "Down with Mubarak", "No to Mubarak", "Mubarak the dictator has fallen" and "Leave, you thief!"]]
Line 98: Line 98:
On the night of 30 January Mubarak's [[Sharm el-Sheikh]] holiday villa was guarded by a small force of armed and loyal police who turned away all approaching vehicles.<ref name="telegraph1">{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/8290760/Locals-in-Sharm-el-Sheikh-convinced-Mubarak-is-holed-up-there.html|title=Locals in Sharm-el-Sheikh convinced Mubarak is holed up there}}</ref> Sharm el-Sheikh had seen no deaths and only a minimal amount of trouble.<ref name="telegraph1" /> A number of [[military aircraft]] were visible from the local airportâs perimeter fence, although the airport is frequently used by the armed forces for operations.<ref name="telegraph1" /> It was also one of the hubs for private air travel in and around Egypt, but most [[light aircraft]] had left the airport earlier in the day.<ref name="telegraph1" />
On the night of 30 January Mubarak's [[Sharm el-Sheikh]] holiday villa was guarded by a small force of armed and loyal police who turned away all approaching vehicles.<ref name="telegraph1">{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/8290760/Locals-in-Sharm-el-Sheikh-convinced-Mubarak-is-holed-up-there.html|title=Locals in Sharm-el-Sheikh convinced Mubarak is holed up there}}</ref> Sharm el-Sheikh had seen no deaths and only a minimal amount of trouble.<ref name="telegraph1" /> A number of [[military aircraft]] were visible from the local airportâs perimeter fence, although the airport is frequently used by the armed forces for operations.<ref name="telegraph1" /> It was also one of the hubs for private air travel in and around Egypt, but most [[light aircraft]] had left the airport earlier in the day.<ref name="telegraph1" />
â
===31 January===
+
==31 January==
The night of 30 January to 31 January was quieter in Cairo, with fewer reports of looting.<ref name="Live blog 30/1 - Egypt protests" /> For the fourth day in a row the curfew was violated without repercussions. Security officials had announced that the curfew would start at 3:00 pm and threatened to shoot anyone who ignored it, although eventually little or no action was taken<ref name="Rian30">{{Cite news|last=Tomasevic|first=Goran|title=Curfew Hours Extended in Egypt as Turmoil Continues|url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20110130/162383449.html|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[RIA Novosti]]|date=30 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Egypt|first=guardian.co.uk|title=Egyptian Protests â Timeline for the Weekend's Events|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/30/egypt-saturday-events-timeline|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[The Guardian]] |date=30 January 2011}}</ref> as security and army personnel left Tahrir Square.
The night of 30 January to 31 January was quieter in Cairo, with fewer reports of looting.<ref name="Live blog 30/1 - Egypt protests" /> For the fourth day in a row the curfew was violated without repercussions. Security officials had announced that the curfew would start at 3:00 pm and threatened to shoot anyone who ignored it, although eventually little or no action was taken<ref name="Rian30">{{Cite news|last=Tomasevic|first=Goran|title=Curfew Hours Extended in Egypt as Turmoil Continues|url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20110130/162383449.html|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[RIA Novosti]]|date=30 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Egypt|first=guardian.co.uk|title=Egyptian Protests â Timeline for the Weekend's Events|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/30/egypt-saturday-events-timeline|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[The Guardian]] |date=30 January 2011}}</ref> as security and army personnel left Tahrir Square.
[[File:EAF Mi-17 over Cairo.jpg|thumb|left|An Egyptian Air Force [[Mi-17]] circling over Tahrir Square]]
[[File:EAF Mi-17 over Cairo.jpg|thumb|left|An Egyptian Air Force [[Mi-17]] circling over Tahrir Square]]
Line 114: Line 114:
<blockquote>The use of violence, with scores dead and injured, is totally incompatible with the policies and principles of any social democratic party anywhere in the world. Consequently, we consider that a party in government that does not listen, that does not move and that does not immediately initiate a process of meaningful change in these circumstances, cannot be a member of the Socialist International. We are, as of today, ceasing the membership of the NDP, however we remain determined to cooperate with all the democrats in Egypt striving to achieve an open, democratic, inclusive and secular state.</blockquote>
<blockquote>The use of violence, with scores dead and injured, is totally incompatible with the policies and principles of any social democratic party anywhere in the world. Consequently, we consider that a party in government that does not listen, that does not move and that does not immediately initiate a process of meaningful change in these circumstances, cannot be a member of the Socialist International. We are, as of today, ceasing the membership of the NDP, however we remain determined to cooperate with all the democrats in Egypt striving to achieve an open, democratic, inclusive and secular state.</blockquote>
â
===1 February â March of the Millions===
+
==1 February â March of the Millions==
[[File:Millionmarchtahrirsquare.jpg|thumb|Tahrir Square during the March of the Millions]]
[[File:Millionmarchtahrirsquare.jpg|thumb|Tahrir Square during the March of the Millions]]
Line 134: Line 134:
{{clear}}
{{clear}}
â
===2 February â Camel Battle===
+
==2 February â Camel Battle==
[[File:Camels_in_Tahrir_Square.Jpgâ|thumb|Camels in Tahrir Square]]
[[File:Camels_in_Tahrir_Square.Jpgâ|thumb|Camels in Tahrir Square]]
[[File:'The March of Millions' - It's in our hands.png|thumb|upright|Protesters in Cairo next to Tahrir Square]]
[[File:'The March of Millions' - It's in our hands.png|thumb|upright|Protesters in Cairo next to Tahrir Square]]
Line 166: Line 166:
Mohammed ElBaradei called on the army to intervene.<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb" /> He also said Mubarak should be given a "safe exit" for Friday's "Departure Day."<ref>{{cite web|author=John Lyons, Cairo |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/hosni-mubarak-must-go-by-friday-says-mohamed-elbaradei/story-e6frg6so-1225998404724 |title=Hosni Mubarak Must Go by Friday, Says Mohamed ElBaradei |work=[[The Australian]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> and that "Today's violence is again an indication of a criminal regime that has lost any commonsense. When the regime tries to counter a peaceful demonstration by using thugs ... there are few words that do justice to this villainy and I think it can only hasten that regime's departure."<ref>{{cite web|author=Staff reporters|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/02/egypt-revolution-turns-ugly|title=Egypt's Revolution Turns Ugly as Mubarak Fights Back|work=[[The Guardian]]|date= 2 February 2011|accessdate= 2 February 2011}}</ref> A coalition of the opposition parties agreed to hold talks with the newly formed government. However, Mohamed ElBaradei and the Muslim Brotherhood stressed they would not talk to any government representative, including Vice President Omar Suleiman, until Mubarak's resignation.<ref>{{cite web|last=Issacharoff |first=Avi |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/is-mubarak-at-the-end-of-his-tether-1.340934 |title=Is Mubarak at the End of His Tether?|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
Mohammed ElBaradei called on the army to intervene.<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb" /> He also said Mubarak should be given a "safe exit" for Friday's "Departure Day."<ref>{{cite web|author=John Lyons, Cairo |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/hosni-mubarak-must-go-by-friday-says-mohamed-elbaradei/story-e6frg6so-1225998404724 |title=Hosni Mubarak Must Go by Friday, Says Mohamed ElBaradei |work=[[The Australian]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> and that "Today's violence is again an indication of a criminal regime that has lost any commonsense. When the regime tries to counter a peaceful demonstration by using thugs ... there are few words that do justice to this villainy and I think it can only hasten that regime's departure."<ref>{{cite web|author=Staff reporters|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/02/egypt-revolution-turns-ugly|title=Egypt's Revolution Turns Ugly as Mubarak Fights Back|work=[[The Guardian]]|date= 2 February 2011|accessdate= 2 February 2011}}</ref> A coalition of the opposition parties agreed to hold talks with the newly formed government. However, Mohamed ElBaradei and the Muslim Brotherhood stressed they would not talk to any government representative, including Vice President Omar Suleiman, until Mubarak's resignation.<ref>{{cite web|last=Issacharoff |first=Avi |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/is-mubarak-at-the-end-of-his-tether-1.340934 |title=Is Mubarak at the End of His Tether?|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
â
===3 February===
+
==3 February==
[[File:A baby Egyptian protesting the government.png|thumb|A baby waving the [[flag of Egypt]] in Tahrir Square]]
[[File:A baby Egyptian protesting the government.png|thumb|A baby waving the [[flag of Egypt]] in Tahrir Square]]
On 2â3 February, 13 people were killed and 1,200 injured, according to the Egyptian health ministry.<ref>{{cite news|title=Egypt protests - live updates|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/feb/03/egypt-protests-live-updates|newspaper=The Guardian|date=3 February 2011}}</ref>
On 2â3 February, 13 people were killed and 1,200 injured, according to the Egyptian health ministry.<ref>{{cite news|title=Egypt protests - live updates|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/feb/03/egypt-protests-live-updates|newspaper=The Guardian|date=3 February 2011}}</ref>
Line 187: Line 187:
Bloomberg reported that Vodafone had been forced by the Egyptian government to send SMS text messages to its customers. The pro-Mubarak messages characterized protesters as un-loyal to the state and had called upon recipients to "confront" them. Vodafone CEO [[Vittorio Colao]] reported that the general public is still being blocked from sending SMS text messages.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-03/vodafone-ordered-to-send-egyptian-government-messages-update1-.html |title=Vodafone Says It Was Instructed to Send Pro-Mubarak Messages to Customers |publisher=bloomberg.com|accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref>
Bloomberg reported that Vodafone had been forced by the Egyptian government to send SMS text messages to its customers. The pro-Mubarak messages characterized protesters as un-loyal to the state and had called upon recipients to "confront" them. Vodafone CEO [[Vittorio Colao]] reported that the general public is still being blocked from sending SMS text messages.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-03/vodafone-ordered-to-send-egyptian-government-messages-update1-.html |title=Vodafone Says It Was Instructed to Send Pro-Mubarak Messages to Customers |publisher=bloomberg.com|accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref>
â
===4 February â Friday of Departure===
+
==4 February â Friday of Departure==
[[File:Tahrir Square during Friday of Departure.png|thumb|Tahrir Square during the "Friday of Departure"]]
[[File:Tahrir Square during Friday of Departure.png|thumb|Tahrir Square during the "Friday of Departure"]]
The same organizers of the "Day of Revolt" and "Friday of Anger" called for a protest which was dubbed the "'''Friday of Departure'''". In Cairo, they planned to march to [[Heliopolis Palace]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/163162.html|title=4 Feb. Declared the 'Friday of Departure'|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Press TV]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|gumÊ¿at ar-raá¸¥Ä«l}}'')<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alraimedia.com/Alrai/Article.aspx?id=253982&date=02022011|title=Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Al Rai]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> They demanded Mubarak step down immediately, with 4 February their deadline for him to surrender his powers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Egypt-Protests-What-Will-Be-The-Future-For-President-Mubarak/Article/201102115920698?lpos=World_News_First_World_News_Article_Teaser_Region_4&lid=ARTICLE_15920698_Egypt_Protests%3A_What_Will_Be_The_Future_For_President_Mubarak|title=What Is the Future for President Mubarak?|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Sky News]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
The same organizers of the "Day of Revolt" and "Friday of Anger" called for a protest which was dubbed the "'''Friday of Departure'''". In Cairo, they planned to march to [[Heliopolis Palace]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/163162.html|title=4 Feb. Declared the 'Friday of Departure'|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Press TV]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|gumÊ¿at ar-raá¸¥Ä«l}}'')<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alraimedia.com/Alrai/Article.aspx?id=253982&date=02022011|title=Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Al Rai]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> They demanded Mubarak step down immediately, with 4 February their deadline for him to surrender his powers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Egypt-Protests-What-Will-Be-The-Future-For-President-Mubarak/Article/201102115920698?lpos=World_News_First_World_News_Article_Teaser_Region_4&lid=ARTICLE_15920698_Egypt_Protests%3A_What_Will_Be_The_Future_For_President_Mubarak|title=What Is the Future for President Mubarak?|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Sky News]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
Line 204: Line 204:
Ahmad Mohamed Mahmoud of ''Al-Ta'awun'' became the first journalist to die covering the protests,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cpj.org/2011/02/press-attacks-cairo-reporter-dies.php |title=(Committee to Protect Journalists) |publisher=Cpj.org |date= |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> from gunshot wounds sustained on 28 January.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/02/white-house-press-secretary-robert-gibbs-said-friday-that-the-obamas-administration-continues-to-receive-very-disturbing-repo.html |title=EGYPT: Reporter who was shot last week dies at local hospital | Babylon & Beyond | Los Angeles Times |publisher=Latimesblogs.latimes.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref>

Line 232: Line 232:
There were also negotiations between Vice President [[Omar Suleiman]] and members from the opposition, including {{link-interwiki|en=Mohammed Morsi|lang=ar|lang_title=ÙØ­ÙØ¯ ÙØ±Ø³Ù}} and [[El-Sayyid el-Badawi]]. The Muslim Brotherhood said it was taking part in a dialogue with the government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 |title=BBC News - Egypt unrest |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> Suleiman agreed to a plan to set up a committee of judiciary and political figures to study constitutional reforms. Penus of the committee are due by early March.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110206/D9L7B7IO0.html |title=Egypt's regime makes new concessions to opposition |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> [[Naguib Sawiris]], who was also involved in the talks, said that "big progress" had been made.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hall |first=Camilla |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-07/egyptian-credit-risk-falling-to-lowest-since-protests-started.html |title=Egypt Credit Risk Falls to Lowest Since Start of Protests as Crisis Eases |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref>

+
==7 February==
[[File:Azharite in Tahrir.jpg|thumb|An [[imam]] of [[Al-Azhar University]], who was wounded in his eye during the protests]]
[[File:Azharite in Tahrir.jpg|thumb|An [[imam]] of [[Al-Azhar University]], who was wounded in his eye during the protests]]
Hundreds of thousands of protesters camped out in Tahrir Square, refusing to budge. A symbolic funeral procession was held for Ahmed Mahmoud in Tahrir Square. Protesters demanded that an investigation be carried out into the cause of his death.<ref>{{cite web|author=Laila Al-Arian |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/anger-in-egypt/2011/02/201126201341479784.html |title=Killed in the line of duty â Anger in Egypt |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref>

===9 February===
+
==9 February==
[[File:Tahrir Square during 9 February evening.jpg|thumb|Tahrir Square during the evening of 9 February]]
[[File:Tahrir Square during 9 February evening.jpg|thumb|Tahrir Square during the evening of 9 February]]
Some protesters moved from Tahrir Square to set up camp in the area outside the parliament buildings, while demanding the assembly's immediate dissolution. The demonstrators put up a sign that said: "Closed until the fall of the regime". The cabinet offices in Cairo were evacuated and officials were relocated after anti-government protesters gathered outside the building. Meanwhile, labour unions across the country, and particularly in Alexandria, Cairo and Suez, staged [[general strike]]s, demanding higher wages and better treatment from their employers. The strikers were said to number around 20,000 workers at various factories in different cities over the past 24 hours.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/20112913546831171.html |title=Workers boost Egypt protests - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Violent clashes were reported in [[Wadi al-Jadid]], where police stations and NDP party building were destroyed, and several deaths and hundreds of injuries also occurred.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/08/live-blog-feb-9-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 9 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref> Protesters in [[Port Said]] burnt down the governor's office in response to his reluctance to provide enough housing for the city's residents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/residents-set-port-said-governorate-hq-alight |title=Residents set Port Said Governorate HQ alight | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Clashes were said to have killed three people and left hundreds more wounded in the past two days.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201129181744289932.html "Egyptians mourn uprising dead"] ''Aljazeera'' - Retrieved 9 February 2011.</ref><!--need to add to casualty table-->
Some protesters moved from Tahrir Square to set up camp in the area outside the parliament buildings, while demanding the assembly's immediate dissolution. The demonstrators put up a sign that said: "Closed until the fall of the regime". The cabinet offices in Cairo were evacuated and officials were relocated after anti-government protesters gathered outside the building. Meanwhile, labour unions across the country, and particularly in Alexandria, Cairo and Suez, staged [[general strike]]s, demanding higher wages and better treatment from their employers. The strikers were said to number around 20,000 workers at various factories in different cities over the past 24 hours.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/20112913546831171.html |title=Workers boost Egypt protests - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Violent clashes were reported in [[Wadi al-Jadid]], where police stations and NDP party building were destroyed, and several deaths and hundreds of injuries also occurred.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/08/live-blog-feb-9-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 9 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref> Protesters in [[Port Said]] burnt down the governor's office in response to his reluctance to provide enough housing for the city's residents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/residents-set-port-said-governorate-hq-alight |title=Residents set Port Said Governorate HQ alight | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Clashes were said to have killed three people and left hundreds more wounded in the past two days.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201129181744289932.html "Egyptians mourn uprising dead"] ''Aljazeera'' - Retrieved 9 February 2011.</ref><!--need to add to casualty table-->
Line 281: Line 281:
Culture Minister [[Gaber Asfour]] resigned after one week in office, citing health problems.<ref>{{cite web|last=Weaver |first=Matthew |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/feb/09/egypt-protests-live-updates-9-february |title=Egypt protests - Wednesday 9 February | News | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref>
Culture Minister [[Gaber Asfour]] resigned after one week in office, citing health problems.<ref>{{cite web|last=Weaver |first=Matthew |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/feb/09/egypt-protests-live-updates-9-february |title=Egypt protests - Wednesday 9 February | News | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref>

Line 302: Line 302:
Eyewitnesses said that the Egyptian army had pulled out troops from many locations near the presidential palace in Cairo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/witnesses-egyptian-army-withdraws-positions-near-presidential-palace |title=Witnesses: Egyptian army withdraws from positions near presidential palace |publisher=Almasryalyoum.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>
Eyewitnesses said that the Egyptian army had pulled out troops from many locations near the presidential palace in Cairo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/witnesses-egyptian-army-withdraws-positions-near-presidential-palace |title=Witnesses: Egyptian army withdraws from positions near presidential palace |publisher=Almasryalyoum.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>

===11 February===
+
==11 February==
[[File:Protesters with soldier.jpg|thumb|200px|A soldier joins the protesters in celebration of Mubarak's downfall.]]
[[File:Protesters with soldier.jpg|thumb|200px|A soldier joins the protesters in celebration of Mubarak's downfall.]]
Shock that Mubarak did not step down on Thursday 10 February resulted in a nationwide escalation of protests on 11 February, named again as the '''"Friday of Departure"''' by the opposition movement.<ref name="signonsandiego1">{{cite news | last = Schemm | first = Paul | last2 = Michael | first2 = Maggie | agency = Associated Press | date = 2011-02-05 | url = http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2011/feb/11/mubarak-leaves-cairo-for-sinai-as-protests-spread/ | title = Mubarak leaves Cairo for Sinai as protests spread | publisher = SignOnSanDiego.com | accessdate = 2011-02-12 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Egypt's army vows smooth transition|date=February 12, 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121217639448807.html|accessdate=February 13, 2011}}</ref> Massive protests continued in Cairo, Alexandria, and other cities. The presidential palace and parliament still remained surrounded by protestors and thousands of people surrounded the state TV building, keeping anyone from entering or leaving. The army issued a ''[[communiquÃ©]]'' in support of Mubarak's attempt to remain ''[[de jure]]'' president while delegating his powers to Vice President Suleiman.<ref>{{citation|title=Egyptian army backs Hosni Mubarak and calls for protesters to go home|ell by .25%url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/11/egyptian-army-backs-hosni-mubarak|first=Paul|last=Owen|date=2011/02/11|publisher=Guardian.co.uk}}</ref> Hossam Badrawi, the new secretary of the NDP, resigned from his position from the party due to his unhappiness with Hosni Mubarak's refusal to step down.<ref>[http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/11/latest-updates-on-day-18-of-egypt-protests/?hp "Latest Updates on Day 18 of Egypt Protests"] by Robert Mackey - ''The New York Times.'.' Retrieved 11 February 2011.</ref>
Shock that Mubarak did not step down on Thursday 10 February resulted in a nationwide escalation of protests on 11 February, named again as the '''"Friday of Departure"''' by the opposition movement.<ref name="signonsandiego1">{{cite news | last = Schemm | first = Paul | last2 = Michael | first2 = Maggie | agency = Associated Press | date = 2011-02-05 | url = http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2011/feb/11/mubarak-leaves-cairo-for-sinai-as-protests-spread/ | title = Mubarak leaves Cairo for Sinai as protests spread | publisher = SignOnSanDiego.com | accessdate = 2011-02-12 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Egypt's army vows smooth transition|date=February 12, 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121217639448807.html|accessdate=February 13, 2011}}</ref> Massive protests continued in Cairo, Alexandria, and other cities. The presidential palace and parliament still remained surrounded by protestors and thousands of people surrounded the state TV building, keeping anyone from entering or leaving. The army issued a ''[[communiquÃ©]]'' in support of Mubarak's attempt to remain ''[[de jure]]'' president while delegating his powers to Vice President Suleiman.<ref>{{citation|title=Egyptian army backs Hosni Mubarak and calls for protesters to go home|ell by .25%url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/11/egyptian-army-backs-hosni-mubarak|first=Paul|last=Owen|date=2011/02/11|publisher=Guardian.co.uk}}</ref> Hossam Badrawi, the new secretary of the NDP, resigned from his position from the party due to his unhappiness with Hosni Mubarak's refusal to step down.<ref>[http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/11/latest-updates-on-day-18-of-egypt-protests/?hp "Latest Updates on Day 18 of Egypt Protests"] by Robert Mackey - ''The New York Times.'.' Retrieved 11 February 2011.</ref>
Line 308: Line 308:
Demonstrators began to gather at new locations in Cairo. The army also surrounded the presidential palace and state television and radio buildings{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} as protesters surrounded the Egyptian radio and television union building demanding fair media coverage from state television. The state television shifted its attitude towards the protesters and begun referring to them as Jan25 Youth Revolution<!--is this precise?-->, admitting mistakes had been made in the media coverage of the protests: "We [the state TV] were under an information chaos," the news anchor stated. "We had strict orders from external sides."<ref>http://www.demotiximages.com/news/587341/egypts-joy-after-mubaraks-step-down</ref> There were also major protests in Alexandria and Mansoura. In [[Arish]], in north Sinai, the second police station in 24 hours came under heavy arms fire â including RPGs â in which at least one protester<!--need to add to total tally--> was killed and 20 injured, with possibly more police fatalities.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}
Demonstrators began to gather at new locations in Cairo. The army also surrounded the presidential palace and state television and radio buildings{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} as protesters surrounded the Egyptian radio and television union building demanding fair media coverage from state television. The state television shifted its attitude towards the protesters and begun referring to them as Jan25 Youth Revolution<!--is this precise?-->, admitting mistakes had been made in the media coverage of the protests: "We [the state TV] were under an information chaos," the news anchor stated. "We had strict orders from external sides."<ref>http://www.demotiximages.com/news/587341/egypts-joy-after-mubaraks-step-down</ref> There were also major protests in Alexandria and Mansoura. In [[Arish]], in north Sinai, the second police station in 24 hours came under heavy arms fire â including RPGs â in which at least one protester<!--need to add to total tally--> was killed and 20 injured, with possibly more police fatalities.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}
â
==== Resignation of Mubarak ====
+
=== Resignation of Mubarak ===
[[File:Finally a free country.jpg|thumb|left|150 px|A protester holding a placard saying "''Finally: a free country.''"]]
[[File:Finally a free country.jpg|thumb|left|150 px|A protester holding a placard saying "''Finally: a free country.''"]]
Vice President Omar Suleiman announced from the Presidential Palace after 18:00 Cairo local time (GMT +2) on 11 February that the presidency had been vacated and the army council would run the country:{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}
Vice President Omar Suleiman announced from the Presidential Palace after 18:00 Cairo local time (GMT +2) on 11 February that the presidency had been vacated and the army council would run the country:{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}
